comments.commentBody:
Some of the reasons why your son may be opting out of most peer group activities is that he is at the age when the conversation may often shift to topics with which he is not (yet?) comfortable -- basically a lot of guff about sex, drugs and pop culture. This is not something he is going to explain to you. It's pretty hard for them to sort this out and he's probably busy sorting it.

Camp (especially overnight camp), sleep-overs, evening outings and any loose, unsupervised groups are land-mines for kids who have never been socially confident.

Put adolescence on top of his natural shyness and diffidence, and you get a situation where staying home "just feels better."

Whether your son has bigger issues on his mind -- serious anxiety or depression, sexual identity issues, world peace -- remains to be seen. As they head into the teen years it becomes much harder to be a pro-active parent. You just don't have enough information anymore and you won't until your child is ready to share it.

You say you've had him in therapy and tried medication. So, you've done your job. He knows your door is always open for conversation.

Don't worry so much, but keep watching and keep the door open.
The Parliament was democratically elected.

Dear Ellie... Low-balling education has not "been rampant throughout the United States." It has been rampant only in those states controlled by Republicans. The GOP exists for one reason only: to cut taxes. And the GOP will cut wherever it can get away with it. Like all bullies, they pick on the kids. It isn't going to change, or go away. Vote GOP, and kiss your children's education goodbye.

It is sad that the voters of the US prefer to cut taxes rather than pay for education of the children of the country. Kansas is an extreme case, but the desire to cut taxes on the back of education has been rampant throughout the United States.
Why don't we want to invest in our future? Is it because our voters are aging and are worrying about whether they will be cared for or not? Very likely I say.
But in the end, I believe it would be tragic if the older people of our country were willing to sacrifice the future of the young people in fear that the young would not take care of the. Perhaps this is a divide that we don't like to admit exists.
Another thick as a brick reactionary in a wall of shame.

Now ... I vote that your views on Texas be distributed free in all Texas schools and nailed to the doors of every church there. I'm sure that the honesty of your conviction that all Texans deserve to be banished to Dante's Hell will get just a TON of cooperation from Texans.

It used to be that this kind of gratuitous and divisive chauvinism wasn't accepted in polite company. But, then, we narrowly elected (and even more narrowly re-elected) Barack Obama, and our entire discourse seems to have descended to "You didn't build that".

Bully for American cohesion. The only people seriously arguing for secession are people like the good dr. bob.

I feel trapped in a teenaged horror movie.
"Southern Mass MurdersLegislated for Christ and FOX" Dir. by Koch and Koch. Written by Newt and Overy. Starring the Circe de Ferdinand the Bull. A death a minute, unless you discout the poor, the Mexicans, and the gays and all women. Then it is just fun.
What happens?
1. Millionaires vote to force poor women, no, all women in need, to find backroom abortions.
2. They refuse ACA for the men and women without government policies voted by themselves, for themselves, and of themselves.
3. They approve of and often employ Mexican workers but will shoot new ones coming for a glass of water.
4. They execute killers but want guns in the airports for everyone.
5. They teach texts that deny slavery was bad or helped create secession.
6. They brag they have an invisible writ from statehood days to vote to secede.
7. They vote away Food Stamps because the poor are "users" and not "workers".
8. They blame Bush's deficits on his successor.

Texas.
It has lots of bulls.
Bulls eat and their appetites make lots of bull stuff.
No wonder Texas smells to high heaven.

Glass half empty, glass half full, I guess. I was appalled by the results, because the Republicans have become so scary. It's sad that the Democrats are so timid, but I'd rather live with that timidity than be governed by a party that seems to have been taken over by the characters in a Charles Addams cartoon.

How many wars in Iraq, Katrinas, government shutdowns, and economic meltdowns will it take before people wise up? After all these years, I would have hoped we would become a little wiser.
They need people to shoot to justify their guns.
Cynical manipulation of  'religious' values to promote a feudal division of wealth seems to be the norm in Texas.

Re: "Why are Republicans so obsessed with sex, eggs and fetuses? Why don't they care about what happens once the fetus is born?"

All the militant and extreme anti-abortionists I've known personally, that is, those who insist that aborting a fertilized egg cell at conception is murder and talk about it often and stridently, have been simply obtuse and misanthropic, in various combinations of degree, but for those with real power--the rich, the corporate, politicians--the idea, I assume, is to make more poor people to exploit economically.

Why are Republicans so obsessed with sex, eggs and fetuses? Why don't they care about what happens once the fetus is born?

And why is Rick Perry such a braggart?

Texas leads the country in uninsured children, with 1.2 million uninsured. In Texas, 22% of children were uninsured, compared to 11% nationally.

About one in four Texans lives at or below the poverty level; for children, it's
nearly one in three.

Among the reasons Texas’ child poverty rate has grown is that despite the state’s relatively low unemployment rate, it has a high rate of jobs that pay minimum wage or less.

Finally, for the first time, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has examined a troubling sub-group: teens who give birth to a second, third or even fourth child. These are called “repeat teen births.” Of all 50 states, Texas ranks #1.

The study from the CDC also shows that 18% of teen births are repeat teen births. Texas has the highest rate, with 22% being repeats. Two-thirds of families begun by a young unmarried mother are poor. One quarter of teen mothers go on welfare within 3 years of the child’s birth. Only 38% of mothers who give birth before 18 get a high school diploma.

So, by not providing health insurance to the poor, by not providing birth control to women, by shutting down abortion clinics in the poorest counties in Texas, Rick Perry and all his fellow Texans are continuing their race to the bottom.

The process of outlawing abortions by making it nearly impossible to keep clinics open will stop some women from getting abortions. Mainly it will stop poor women and people, like a 15 year old without any money or sympathetic parents.

So much of the time, Republican policies seem to be aimed at helping the poor to stay poor or in denying them options in life and, on the other hand, protecting the wealth of those already rich. They are all against the intrusions of govt. in people's lives, except when it comes to their sexual practices, their reproductive processes and that of the the state in deciding to take the ultimate step against the individual, the death penalty. Those things are all good, according to so called conservatives. How do people live with such bold faced contradictions? I'd like to know and I would like to know why so many middle class citizens buy into it.

Dooley Wilson would have been a good trick today, but no Chicago connection, I don't think.

As it stands, I'm back at square one, once again.

Leapy,

Is "Jews in sports" a spoiler?
Martin, there is a least one advantage to the new format. Your threepeats are now spread apart.

Howie, I might be more Scottish than Irish but it's for sure I have both bloods running through my veins. This puzzle was just another walk in the park.

Martin, you could go all the way and say how much you enjoyed the puzzle.
The emails are extremely germane to proving "criminal intent," which along with the actual criminal acts, i.e., the false accounting entries, completes the legal definition of a criminal act.
Yeltsin also said later that if he had known who the real Putin was he would have not brought Putin up to replace him.  He said it was his biggest mistake he made as President.

Putin 1.0 really did pull Russia out of free fall. That fact cannot be disputed. He could have quietly left the president's office and retired from politics and he would have been rather revered by the Russians for putting an end to the dark days of Yeltsin.

But, his megalomania got the better of him and when Putin 2.0 showed up, things went steadily downhill. [It was suggested to me by a local that Putin had to return to office to avoid prison.]

His hard right turn on social issues and his military bluster are doing nothing to endear him to the population, that's for sure, save for those fed a steady diet of how great Putin is from the Kremlin controlled media.

As the economy continues to slow, things will only get worse for Putin. And, if western sanctions really start to bite [McDonald's shutting its doors would send millions of teens into the streets in protest, no doubt.], his rule will become untenable to a population that has traveled outside of Russia and who have seen how other people live.

I really do not understand this foray into Crimea. It will not end for Putin.

Putin's disconnection from reality reminds me of Richard Nixon's last days. Nixon surrounded himself with men that only told him what he wanted to hear and he initiated illegal activities designed to keep him in office. The constraints and three branched nature of the US government led to his resignation. Russia does not have such constraints on the concentration of power at the top, his removal would appear to be almost impossible unless the corrupt Russian oligarchs remove him or widespread popular dissent force him from office.

Mr. Putin made two fateful decisions in his tenure. The first was shortly after he took the helm, he made a choice to stir Russia away from further integration with Europe and toward Soviet style domestic and foreign policy. This decision established the path toward corrupt, venal authoritarian petro-state that enriched him and his circle beyond the wildest imagination, but produced stagnant, centrally driven economy wholly dependent on oil and gas. His decision to invade Crimea sealed Russia away from Europe and the west for the duration of his tenure. He had to have known that Russia will be isolated and set to economically disintegrate over time. But he calculated that the rise of nationalism and soviet style paranoia will carry him for while and will inoculate him from any attempts by people or the oligarchs to dethrone him. Better together in a slowly sinking ship, then exposed to criticism and risk over economy and lack of freedom.  A tragedy for the Russian people, who have seen plenty of them.
Then why not NATO offer Russia to join it as well? They don't want Russia in the NATO because there can only be one boss in the group, it is the US
We don't want Russia in the group because NATO is designed to protect against Russia; the concern about which is vindicated by Russia's current actions.

Why are so many commentators who are so critical of the NATO expansion forgetting that the countries now part of NATO also played the role? It is not like the Baltic states were occupied by NATO. They wanted to be a part of it and for a very good reason. Poland has joined the West at its own will! It is a member of the EU and NATO, again for an extremely good reason.

These countries are not just passive non-agents. Many of them suffered a great deal under the Soviet regime and have decided, democratically, to join and become a part of the Western world. They had not been Russian territories although most had been occupied by the Soviets in one way or another.

All the commentators as well as Tom Freedman who view the eastward expansion of NATO as a mistake should see how liberty, economy and democracy have progressed in most of those states, despite the European economic near-catastrophe, and should stop ignoring the will of their citizens to join NATO and EU at that time.
In the end, who controls Crimea won't amount to a hill of beans.  The greater harm here is that the hope of big power cooperation in Syria and Iran have just gone up in smoke.

Long before some BRITE bartender concocted the MOJITO, the Mucho Grande highball of choice out of Havana was the Cuba Libre!

Welcome back Deb, to the WP NEST, we do hereby SWEAR that we missed you!

Howie

Obama said:

“Any discussion about the future of Ukraine must include the legitimate government of Ukraine...In 2014, we are well beyond the days when borders can be redrawn over the heads of democratic leaders.”

"The legitimate government of Ukraine?" Which one would that be?

Most of those borders were torn apart by the Yugoslavs long before NATO intervened. Slovenia, Bosnia and Croatia had broken away and NATO intervention only helped decided where the borders actually ended up. You might also note that NATO intervention took place in response to Serb atrocities the like of which you don't see in Crimea.

" accidentally on purpose?"
You have some proof of this?

Russia acts as any nation that is getting surrounded by enemy(NATO).
NATO's movement to the east shows that it sees Russia as an enemy.
It is a Putins responsibility to safeguard lives and freedom of 135 million Russian citizens. They can't allow Ukraine to join NATO, to risky from security standpoint to allow NATO to come so close to it's western borders.
Putin is not crazy, he is responsible leader!
The solution to 9/11 was for us to annex the petroleum-rich lands Iraq and Afghanistan.  The solution to Crimea is for us to expand natural gas production.  Are you catching on?

What exactly  did we do to Syria and Lebanon, especially to the latter? I would love to learn the specifics.  Also, US is not too far from Russian Far East and China, and Central Europe is a stone throw away from Western regions of Russia. So why do we need to get even closer to the borders of China or Russia?

Gaining Control -They're taking over countries in North Africa, middle east, near east. Libya, they're into Syria. They started trouble in Lebanon, Iraq, they're in Afghanistan and they want Iran with objectives of getting on the borders of China and Russia.

And what they're doing is finding different excuses or people might think there's a pattern here.

Oh wait! That's not Russia! That's us! (sorry)

You mean NATO's actions with respect to the atrocities that occurred with the breakup with Yugoslavia and later under Milosevic's rule in Serbia? Not sure how that is even relevant with respect to Putin's invasion of Crimea, I don't even think response to this ranks as "Do two wrongs make a right?" as NATO's actions in the fore-mentioned were correct. The bombing of the Chinese was by all evidence a mistake. NATO forces were never even involved in the Georgia and Russia dispute over Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Whatever proposals may have existed for NATO plans to break up Syria were not put into motion. The invasions of Iraq, occurred under past US administrations, and were opposed by many in the US including President Obama at the time he was a Senator. I don't see the relevancy of the examples you bring up with respect to Russia's current invasion of Crimea.

Crimea annexed today.

Eastern Ukraine next month.

After that: the Baltic states - particularly Latvia which has a corporation of "repressed" ethnic Russians.

Latvia is a card carrying NATO member. Thus, an attack on Latvia is identical, according to the NATO treaty at least, as an attack on all other NATO members. (It will not actually be an attack, but rather "support of ethnic Russians by members of local Russian patriots protecting their rights".)

But, when Russia moves into Latvia 50,000 troops and 1,000 tanks, backed by ground attack helicopters and a few destroyers anchored in the harbor, does anyone honestly think the West will wage war over a country no one has ever heard of?

Back to the USSR!
Somebody won the Cuban Missile Crisis?
I would hardly say we turned our back on Israel.

"The Right Sector movement, a nationalist group ...the group was prepared to fight, in Crimea and elsewhere, 'if the Kremlin tramples on us further.'"

As if Right Sector has any strength in the Crimea. The Right Sector are violent neo-Nazis as you can see by their belligerent attitude,
What makes you think vote will be free and fair?
